summary:
A norm is a special function that measures the "distance" from the origin in a vector space. It has three key rules: it scales with the vector, follows a version of the triangle inequality, and is zero only at the origin. The Euclidean distance we know is an example, called the Euclidean norm.

A seminorm is similar but can be zero for some non-origin vectors. A normed vector space has a specified norm, while a seminormed space has a seminorm. Sometimes, "pseudonorm" is used to describe a seminorm or a norm with slightly different rules, allowing for inequality or infinite values.
title: Norm (mathematics)
